results.title: Angkor, the lost city
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Angkor - a whole metropolis of palaces and temples recovered from the jungle which hid them for centuries until discovered in 1860 by a French naturalist. Monuments, picture tapestries in stone and Angkor Vat, a mile square temple of grey sandstone which no other church has rivalled in size, reveal the glories of the past empire of the Khmers, ancestors of the Cambodians.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Alpine Playground
results.creator_credit: Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound
results.brief_description: A holiday with a difference; the joys of an alpine winter holiday in Victoria’s picturesque skiing resorts, Mt Buffalo, Mt Hotham and Falls Creek. Within easy reach of Melbourne, facilities include expert ski instruction, readily available ski tows, toboggans, and comfortable accommodation.

results.title: Adam and Eve
results.brief_description: An animated film using abstract cutouts, symbolising life, reproduction, growth and destruction from creation to the end of the world in an explosion, then the beginning of a new cycle.

results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: First Nations people of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.

results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.

results.title: Fifty Years of Service
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: The first fifty years of the State Electricity Commission is presented by means of archival film detailing highlights of the development of the power authority for Victoria - from 1919 to the completion of the giant Hazelwood power complex.

results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [1-hour compilation]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DJ and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This one-hour compilation was created a month after the event from nine hours of footage and subsequently aired July 12, 1992.

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

results.title: Dottie gets spanked
results.brief_description: Todd Haynes’ black comedy is set in 1950s suburbia where the TV heroine Dottie reigns supreme. When a young boy gets his chance to meet his idol, the series of events he witnesses transforms his fantasy life. This is where childhood’s end begins.

results.title: Double concerto: a film about the pianist Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Angela Catterns, Abstract Productions, Endeavour Film Productions and Hugh Piper
results.brief_description: The star of “Double Concerto” is the brilliant Australian pianist Roger Woodward. His inspiration and fellow musician is the equally brilliant Polish violinist, Wanda Wilkomirska. Together they play the double concerto “Southern Cross”, a concerto written especially for them by Australia’s most internationally acclaimed composer, Barry Conyingham. The film follows Roger and Wanda in rehearsal, in concert and in rambling walks along the sea shores. They discuss their music, their politics and their personal lives.

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
